aliases.name: Green Monster
aliases.meaning: Named for its glowing green appearance

description.summary: A 10-12 foot tall entity with a spade-shaped head, glowing red face, and metallic body encountered in Flatwoods, West Virginia on September 12, 1952, following a UFO sighting.
description.full: The Flatwoods Monster, also known as the Braxton County Monster, is an entity reportedly encountered on September 12, 1952, in Flatwoods, West Virginia. The encounter began when local boys witnessed a bright object cross the sky and apparently land on the property of local farmer G. Bailey Fisher. A group including Kathleen May, her two sons, their friend Gene Lemon (a National Guardsman), and several other boys went to investigate. They reported encountering a 10-12 foot tall figure with a spade-shaped head, glowing red face, and a dark metallic body that appeared to hover or float. The entity allegedly emitted a hissing sound and released a mist that caused nausea and breathing difficulties in the witnesses. The incident was investigated by journalist Gray Barker and gained national attention. Skeptical explanations suggest the witnesses may have encountered a barn owl perched on a tree branch, with the 'UFO' being a meteor, though this explanation remains disputed.

etymology.origin: Named after Flatwoods, West Virginia, the location of the encounter

related_phenomena.name: Hopkinsville Goblins
related_phenomena.description: Another 1950s entity encounter in nearby Kentucky

features.description: Glowing red face or eyes within the head area
Dark metallic or green body, appeared mechanical or robotic
Appeared to hover or glide rather than walk
Arms described, legs uncertain - may have been hovering

physical.morphology: Extremely tall figure with distinctive spade-shaped head, metallic appearance, and glowing red facial area. Body appeared dark and possibly mechanical. Movement suggested floating or hovering.

abilities.description: Entity appeared to float or hover above ground
Released a mist or gas that caused nausea and breathing difficulties
Emitted a hissing or mechanical sound
Face or eyes emitted red glow

patterns: Did not pursue witnesses when they fled

range.description: Single encounter location in Flatwoods, Braxton County, West Virginia

hotspots.name: Fisher Farm
hotspots.notes: Single encounter location; no subsequent confirmed sightings

first_recorded.source: Multiple witness accounts and contemporary news reports

origins.cultural_roots: Part of 1950s wave of UFO and alien entity reports in United States
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to broader UFO contactee era and Cold War anxieties

timeline.significance: Boys witness bright object cross sky and land on Fisher farm; group investigates and encounters entity
Story reaches local and national press
Journalist and UFO researcher Gray Barker arrives to investigate
Story featured in newspapers nationwide, becoming one of most famous UFO entity encounters
Joe Nickell proposes barn owl explanation for the entity
Flatwoods embraces the monster as local icon; museum and annual festival established

history.modern_era: The Flatwoods Monster has become a cultural icon in West Virginia, with the town of Flatwoods celebrating the legend through a museum, annual festival, and various commemorations. The incident is considered one of the most significant UFO-related entity encounters of the 1950s.

notable.name: The Flatwoods Encounter

location.description: G. Bailey Fisher farm, Flatwoods, Braxton County

notable.description: On the evening of September 12, 1952, brothers Edward and Fred May, along with their friend Tommy Hyer, witnessed a bright object cross the sky and land on the nearby Fisher farm. They enlisted Kathleen May (the boys' mother), local National Guardsman Eugene 'Gene' Lemon, and brothers Neil Nunley and Ronnie Shaver to investigate. As the group climbed the hill, they reported a pungent mist that caused breathing difficulties and nausea. Gene Lemon's dog ran ahead and began barking, then came running back in apparent fear. The group encountered a large pulsating ball of fire. When Lemon shone his flashlight toward a nearby oak tree, they saw a 10-12 foot tall figure with a spade-shaped head, glowing red face, and dark metallic body that appeared to hover. The entity emitted a hissing sound. Terrified, the group fled. Several witnesses became ill afterward, experiencing symptoms including vomiting, convulsions, and irritated throats. Local sheriff Robert Carr and deputy Burnell Long investigated the site later that night, finding skid marks and an area of flattened grass with a strange odor, but no entity.
evidence: Physical effects on witnesses (nausea, vomiting, throat irritation)
Flattened grass and skid marks at site
Strange odor reported by multiple parties

factors: Possible misidentification of barn owl and meteor
credibility.notes: One of most documented UFO entity encounters of 1950s. Skeptics propose barn owl misidentification, but witnesses maintained consistent accounts. Physical symptoms suggest genuine frightening experience, whether entity was extraterrestrial, animal, or misperception.

sources: Feschino, F. (2004). The Braxton County Monster

physical.name: Flattened grass and skid marks
physical.description: Sheriff's investigation found area of flattened grass and marks on the ground at the encounter site
physical.analysis: Contemporary investigation noted disturbance; no samples preserved for modern analysis

physical.name: Strange odor
physical.description: Pungent, metallic smell reported by witnesses and later by sheriff's investigators
physical.analysis: Multiple witnesses reported smell; caused physical reactions. No samples collected.

trace.name: Witness illness
trace.description: Multiple witnesses experienced nausea, vomiting, throat irritation, and in some cases convulsions following exposure
trace.analysis: Symptoms consistent with extreme fear response or possible exposure to irritant. No medical records preserved.

paranormal.name: Extraterrestrial entity
paranormal.description: Entity was extraterrestrial being associated with UFO landing

paranormal.name: Alien reconnaissance
paranormal.description: Entity was extraterrestrial scout or robotic probe from crashed or landed craft

skeptical.name: Barn owl misidentification
skeptical.description: Witnesses encountered a barn owl perched on tree branch, with meteor sighting creating UFO expectation
evidence_cited: Barn owl heart-shaped face resembles 'spade shape'
Owls can appear large at night

skeptical.name: Mass hysteria
skeptical.description: Initial meteor sighting combined with fear, darkness, and expectation created shared misperception
evidence_cited: Physical symptoms consistent with extreme fear

skeptical.name: Embellishment
skeptical.description: Initial encounter with mundane object or animal embellished by witnesses and investigators
evidence_cited: Gray Barker known for embellishing UFO cases

stories: Various embellished retellings in cryptid literature
folklore.beliefs: Ranges from genuine belief in extraterrestrial encounter to local pride in famous legend

literature: Barker, G. (1956). They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers
Feschino, F. (2004). The Braxton County Monster
film_tv: Secret of the Flying Saucer (1956) - possibly inspired by incident
games: Fallout 76 - features Flatwoods Monster as enemy creature
other: Town of Flatwoods embraces as mascot

researchers.name: Gray Barker
researchers.contribution: First investigator on scene; documented case extensively (though known for embellishment)

researchers.name: Frank Feschino Jr.
researchers.contribution: Extensive research and book on Braxton County Monster

researchers.name: Joe Nickell
researchers.contribution: Proposed barn owl explanation through analysis of witness descriptions

organizations.name: Flatwoods Monster Museum
organizations.focus: Preservation of encounter history and local culture

research.ongoing_studies: Limited active research. Primarily historical and cultural interest. Case remains point of debate between UFO researchers and skeptics.

sources.title: The Braxton County Monster: The Cover-Up of the Flatwoods Monster Revealed
They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers
Various newspaper accounts
sources.description: Contemporary coverage in Charleston Gazette, local West Virginia papers, and national news services
